articles.headline: Sales Plunge Adds to Chrysler’s Misery
articles.snippet: The preliminary estimates raise doubts about the likelihood of even a modest recovery in the months ahead.
articles.abstract: The preliminary estimates raise doubts about the likelihood of even a modest recovery in the months ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Chrysler’s sales fell 48 percent in April, underscoring the challenge it faces in trying to attract buyers while it reorganizes in bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Wider World of Choices to Fill Souter’s Vacancy
articles.snippet: Many expect President Obama to choose a woman to replace Justice David H. Souter — and he has a lot of choices.
articles.abstract: Many expect President Obama to choose a woman to replace Justice David H. Souter — and he has a lot of choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Ronald Reagan decided to appoint a woman to the Supreme Court in 1981, he had to turn to Sandra Day O’Connor, an obscure state judge.

articles.headline: Citi Is Said to Require New Capital
articles.snippet: The bank believes it can raise funds to satisfy regulators through asset sales and a big stock conversion plan.
articles.abstract: The bank believes it can raise funds to satisfy regulators through asset sales and a big stock conversion plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is locked in negotiations with federal regulators over whether it needs to raise as much as $10 billion in fresh capital as a result of the government’s stress test of its financial health, according to a person briefed on the situation.

articles.headline: Don’t Ask. You Can Afford It.
articles.snippet: As the recession bites hard, dollar stores are popping up like dandelions at new locations. Many are also expanding their food offerings.
articles.abstract: As the recession bites hard, dollar stores are popping up like dandelions at new locations. Many are also expanding their food offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart may have become the premier place to shop for Americans struggling through a severe recession, but the giant chain has competition nipping at its heels.

articles.headline: Does God Want You to Be Bankrupt?
articles.snippet: Some of the world’s religions have advice on how to deal with people who are deeply in debt.
articles.abstract: Some of the world’s religions have advice on how to deal with people who are deeply in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, yet another Washington debate over who deserves a break on their debts drew to a close. On Thursday, the Senate voted against allowing judges to adjust the terms of the mortgages of people filing for personal bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Same Data, Conflicting Forecasts
articles.snippet: Are we surfacing from a financial crisis, or getting in deeper? The data can be persuasive for either side.
articles.abstract: Are we surfacing from a financial crisis, or getting in deeper? The data can be persuasive for either side.
articles.lead_paragraph: So where were we?

articles.headline: Suit in Madoff Case Says a Manager Was Favored
articles.snippet: The suit says Stanley Chais got such large returns on his family’s accounts with Bernard L. Madoff that he “knew or should have known” that there was illegal activity.
articles.abstract: The suit says Stanley Chais got such large returns on his family’s accounts with Bernard L. Madoff that he “knew or should have known” that there was illegal activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A court-appointed trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff case has accused Stanley Chais, an investment manager and prominent Los Angeles philanthropist, of routinely getting “implausibly high” returns on his family’s Madoff accounts  profits so high that he should have known they were the product of a fraud.

articles.headline: In Pakistan, U.S. Courts Leader of Opposition
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is reaching out to the former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, whose ties to Islamists could help President Asif Ali Zardari confront the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is reaching out to the former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, whose ties to Islamists could help President Asif Ali Zardari confront the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As American confidence in the Pakistani government wanes, the Obama administration is reaching out more directly than before to Nawaz Sharif, the chief rival of Asif Ali Zardari, the Pakistani president, administration officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Obama Has Chance to Select Justice With Varied Résumé
articles.snippet: As Justice David H. Souter departs, the president could move the court back toward what it has been for most of its history: a collection of prominent individuals with broad experience.
articles.abstract: As Justice David H. Souter departs, the president could move the court back toward what it has been for most of its history: a collection of prominent individuals with broad experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The current Supreme Court, made up entirely of former federal appeals court judges, is in some ways the most insulated and homogenous in American history.

articles.headline: Union Takes Rare Front Seat in Deal for Chrysler
articles.snippet: Labor unions usually dread bankruptcy, but the United Automobile Workers union stands to benefit in Chrysler’s case — if the automaker thrives.
articles.abstract: Labor unions usually dread bankruptcy, but the United Automobile Workers union stands to benefit in Chrysler’s case — if the automaker thrives.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Labor unions usually dread bankruptcy, and for good reason. Their pay, benefits and pensions typically suffer significant cuts, as airline and steel workers can attest.

articles.headline: U.S. May Revive Guantánamo Military Courts
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is moving toward reviving a policy that the president himself had criticized.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is moving toward reviving a policy that the president himself had criticized.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is moving toward reviving the military commission system for prosecuting Guantánamo detainees, which was a target of critics during the Bush administration, including Mr. Obama himself.

articles.headline: Voices Reflect Rising Sense of Racial Optimism
articles.snippet: More Americans indicated that they were feeling optimistic about race relations, yet no one claimed that racial prejudice has disappeared.
articles.abstract: More Americans indicated that they were feeling optimistic about race relations, yet no one claimed that racial prejudice has disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE  Although the civil rights movement gave Samuel Sallis equality under the law a long time ago, he was left wanting most of his life, he says, for the subtle courtesies and respect he thought would come with it. Being a working-class black man downtown here meant being mostly ignored, living a life invisible and unacknowledged in a larger white world.

articles.headline: Chrysler’s Fall May Help Obama to Reshape G.M.
articles.snippet: If the Chrysler legal process unfolds as the White House hopes it will in coming weeks, the bankruptcy option may look increasingly attractive for General Motors as well.
articles.abstract: If the Chrysler legal process unfolds as the White House hopes it will in coming weeks, the bankruptcy option may look increasingly attractive for General Motors as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fresh from pushing Chrysler into bankruptcy, President Obama and his economic team are hoping that the hard line they took last week gives them leverage to force huge changes in General Motors, a far larger and more complex company.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Students’ First Lesson: Beware Loans’ Fine Print
articles.snippet: Private student loans have become more attractive in this economy, but financial disclosures in the market are uneven.
articles.abstract: Private student loans have become more attractive in this economy, but financial disclosures in the market are uneven.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH school seniors, thrilled at receiving fat envelopes from the colleges of their choice last month, must now figure out how to pay for the privilege of attending these institutions. For many, this will mean a journey into private student loan land, where financial fog and fine print reign.

articles.headline: How Lehman Brothers Got Its Real Estate Fix
articles.snippet: A deal maker at Lehman pioneered ways to package debt that brought huge profits but set off the bank’s collapse.
articles.abstract: A deal maker at Lehman pioneered ways to package debt that brought huge profits but set off the bank’s collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: BACK when he was a major Wall Street deal maker, Mark A. Walsh, the former head of the global real estate group at Lehman Brothers, had a running joke with Carmine Visone, one of his managing directors. Mr. Visone, 10 years older than his boss, would lecture Mr. Walsh about the importance of fundamentals: land values, construction cost and rents.

articles.headline: Here Comes the Sun. Right?
articles.snippet: Despite the recession, a German solar company sees the United States as a promising market.
articles.abstract: Despite the recession, a German solar company sees the United States as a promising market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillsboro, Ore.

articles.headline: As a Professor, Obama Held Pragmatic Views on Court
articles.snippet: President Obama will likely favor a pragmatist with a limited view of the role of courts, former colleagues and students said.
articles.abstract: President Obama will likely favor a pragmatist with a limited view of the role of courts, former colleagues and students said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many American presidents have been lawyers, but almost none have come to office with Barack Obama’s knowledge of the Supreme Court. Before he was 30, he was editing articles by eminent legal scholars on the court’s decisions. Later, as a law professor, he led students through landmark cases from Plessy v. Ferguson to Bush v. Gore. (He sometimes shared his own copies, marked with emphatic underlines and notes in bold, all-caps script.)

articles.headline: Jack Kemp, Star on Field and in Politics, Dies at 73
articles.snippet: Mr. Kemp, a former football star turned congressman, moved the Republican Party to a commitment to tax cuts as the central focus of economic policy.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kemp, a former football star turned congressman, moved the Republican Party to a commitment to tax cuts as the central focus of economic policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Kemp, the former football star turned congressman who with an evangelist’s fervor moved the Republican Party to a commitment to tax cuts as the central focus of economic policy, died Saturday evening at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 73.

articles.headline: A Life Selling Pontiacs, and Feeling Sold Out
articles.snippet: For family dealerships that have tied their names to Pontiac for generations, the closing of the brand hits hard.
articles.abstract: For family dealerships that have tied their names to Pontiac for generations, the closing of the brand hits hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Pa.

articles.abstract: Pakistan’s poorest families have turned to Islamic schools that feed and house children while pushing a militant brand of Islam.

articles.headline: Worries Rise on the Size of U.S. Debt
articles.snippet: The government is digging itself deeper into debt, but the market for Treasuries is not infinite and interest payments are expected to balloon.
articles.abstract: The government is digging itself deeper into debt, but the market for Treasuries is not infinite and interest payments are expected to balloon.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s debt clock is ticking faster than ever  and Wall Street is getting worried.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Newspapers’ Essential Strengths
articles.snippet: A current accounting of the news business — grim and grimmer by the day — suggests that there may be a subsequent bear market in accountability as well.
articles.abstract: A current accounting of the news business — grim and grimmer by the day — suggests that there may be a subsequent bear market in accountability as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reporters like to think of themselves as essential to the national well-being, which might be just one more measure of how out of touch we are, but journalists are not the only ones who are suggesting as much.

articles.headline: Mini-Links to Web Sites Are Multiplying
articles.snippet: Services that abbreviate long Web addresses are growing and may have commercial value because of their ability to track Internet use.
articles.abstract: Services that abbreviate long Web addresses are growing and may have commercial value because of their ability to track Internet use.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have spent any time on the Internet in the last few months, chances are you have clicked on a shortened link Web address.

articles.headline: An Upstart Gossip Site With a Gentler Tone Is Making a Big Splash
articles.snippet: In three months, Wonderwall has jumped to the top tier of celebrity-news sites, occupying a middle ground that’s not too tame, but not too rancorous.
articles.abstract: In three months, Wonderwall has jumped to the top tier of celebrity-news sites, occupying a middle ground that’s not too tame, but not too rancorous.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Web got something in February nobody knew it needed: another celebrity gossip site. Ho-hum and back to TMZ, E! Online, UsMagazine.com and the crowd of other star-watching sites, right?

articles.headline: Pakistan Strife Raises U.S. Doubt on Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: Fears about control of a weapons arsenal increase as an insurgency by the Taliban and Al Qaeda expands its reach.
articles.abstract: Fears about control of a weapons arsenal increase as an insurgency by the Taliban and Al Qaeda expands its reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the insurgency of the Taliban and Al Qaeda spreads in Pakistan, senior American officials say they are increasingly concerned about new vulnerabilities for Pakistan’s nuclear arsenal, including the potential for militants to snatch a weapon in transport or to insert sympathizers into laboratories or fuel-production facilities.

articles.headline: Tests of Banks May Bring Hope More Than Fear
articles.snippet: The Obama administration seems ready to argue that the financial system is healthier than many investors fear.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration seems ready to argue that the financial system is healthier than many investors fear.
articles.lead_paragraph: The results of the bank stress tests to be released by the Obama administration this week are expected to include more detailed information about individual banks  assessing specific parts of their loan portfolios  than many analysts have been expecting.

articles.headline: U.S. Media See a Path to India in China’s Snub
articles.snippet: After years of frustration with China’s rules and censors, entertainment giants are shifting their efforts to India.
articles.abstract: After years of frustration with China’s rules and censors, entertainment giants are shifting their efforts to India.
articles.lead_paragraph: After many years of fervent lobbying and deal-making in China, American media companies have little to show for their efforts there and are increasingly shifting their attention instead to India.

articles.headline: Looking to Big-Screen E-Readers to Help Save the Daily Press
articles.snippet: Several companies are on the verge of introducing devices about the size of a standard sheet of paper, which could carry updated news and ads in a format similar to that of a newspaper.
articles.abstract: Several companies are on the verge of introducing devices about the size of a standard sheet of paper, which could carry updated news and ads in a format similar to that of a newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iPod stemmed losses in the music industry. The Kindle gave beleaguered book publishers a reason for optimism.

articles.headline: Despite Obama’s Talk, Little Bump for Chrysler Sales
articles.snippet: Slow sales of Chrysler vehicles around the country suggest that few were moved by the president’s plea to help Detroit’s automakers by buying an American car.
articles.abstract: Slow sales of Chrysler vehicles around the country suggest that few were moved by the president’s plea to help Detroit’s automakers by buying an American car.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Car salesman was probably not among the jobs that President Obama expected to assume during his first few months in the White House.

articles.headline: S.&P. 500 Erases 2009 Losses as Stocks Jump
articles.snippet: As stocks climbed on Monday, a leading stock index crossed a milestone that seemed unthinkable during the worst declines of the bear market: It turned positive for the year.
articles.abstract: As stocks climbed on Monday, a leading stock index crossed a milestone that seemed unthinkable during the worst declines of the bear market: It turned positive for the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many investors, breaking even never felt so good.

articles.headline: Even as Fears of Flu Ebb, Mexicans Feel Stigma
articles.snippet: Mexicans around the world say they have been cast as disease carriers and subjected to humiliating treatment.
articles.abstract: Mexicans around the world say they have been cast as disease carriers and subjected to humiliating treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Medical experts are calling the new influenza virus A(H1N1), but for many Mexicans it is simply a scarlet A.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and Andrew Jacobs
